markdownRemark.excerpt: This is the fifth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series, and the last post about group theory. In this post, we will finalize our tool box by…
markdownRemark.html:
This is the fifth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series, and the last post about group theory. In this post, we will finalize our tool box by introducing automorphisms, direct products, and semi-direct products. Finally, we can start to harvest our efforts with group classification.

  • Direct Products
  • Automorphisms
  • Classification of Finitely Generated Abelian Groups
  • Semi-Direct Products
  • Examples of Group Classification
  • References

Direct Products

Definition 5.1: Direct Products

If G1,G2,⋯ ,GnG_1, G_2, \cdots, G_nG1​,G2​,⋯,Gn​ are groups, the direct products of the groups, denoted by G1×G2×⋯×GnG_1 \times G_2 \times \cdots \times G_nG1​×G2​×⋯×Gn​, is the direct products of the sets with following binary operation, (g1,g2,⋯ ,gn)∘(g1′,g2′,⋯ ,gn′)=(g1∘1g1′,g2∘2g2′,⋯ ,gn∘ngn′)(g_1, g_2, \cdots, g_n) \circ (g_1', g_2', \cdots, g_n') = (g_1 \circ_1 g_1', g_2 \circ_2 g_2', \cdots, g_n \circ_n g_n')(g1​,g2​,⋯,gn​)∘(g1′​,g2′​,⋯,gn′​)=(g1​∘1​g1′​,g2​∘2​g2′​,⋯,gn​∘n​gn′​).

Proposition 5.2: Direct Products

If G1×G2×⋯×GnG_1 \times G_2 \times \cdots \times G_nG1​×G2​×⋯×Gn​ is a direct product of nnn groups,

  1. For each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], there exists a subjective homomorphism πi:G1×G2×⋯×Gn→Gi\pi_i: G_1 \times G_2 \times \cdots \times G_n \to G_iπi​:G1​×G2​×⋯×Gn​→Gi​, where πi((g1,⋯ ,gn))=gi\pi_i((g_1, \cdots, g_n)) = g_iπi​((g1​,⋯,gn​))=gi​.
  2. For each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], there exists a injective homomorphism ψi:Gi→G1×G2×⋯×Gn\psi_i: G_i \to G_1 \times G_2 \times \cdots \times G_nψi​:Gi​→G1​×G2​×⋯×Gn​, where ψi(gi)=(e1,⋯ ,gi,⋯ ,en)\psi_i(g_i) = (e_1, \cdots, g_i, \cdots, e_n)ψi​(gi​)=(e1​,⋯,gi​,⋯,en​).
  3. G1×G2×⋯×Gn≅Gσ(1)×Gσ(2)×⋯×Gσ(n)G_1 \times G_2 \times \cdots \times G_n \cong G_\sigma(1) \times G_\sigma(2) \times \cdots \times G_\sigma(n)G1​×G2​×⋯×Gn​≅Gσ​(1)×Gσ​(2)×⋯×Gσ​(n) for σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​.

Proposition 5.3: Recognition Principle of Direct Products (Internal Direct Products)

If GGG is a group, and H,KH, KH,K are two normal subgroups such that HK=GHK = GHK=G and H∩K={e}H \cap K = \{e\}H∩K={e}, then G≅H×KG \cong H \times KG≅H×K. We say GGG is the internal direct product of HHH and KKK.

Automorphisms

Definition 5.4: Automorphism For a group GGG, an automorphism is an isomorphism from GGG to itself. Aut(G)Aut(G)Aut(G) denotes the set of all automorphisms.

Proposition 5.5: The Conjugation Action and Automorphism

  1. If H⊴GH \trianglelefteq GH⊴G, the action of GGG acting on HHH by conjugation is a homomorphism of GGG to Aut(H)Aut(H)Aut(H). The kernel of the action is CG(H)C_G(H)CG​(H), and thus G/CG(H)≅ a subgroup of Aut(G)G/C_G(H) \cong \text{ a subgroup of } Aut(G)G/CG​(H)≅ a subgroup of Aut(G).
  2. If H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G, NG(H)/CG(H)≅ a subgroup of Aut(G)N_G(H)/C_G(H) \cong \text{ a subgroup of } Aut(G)NG​(H)/CG​(H)≅ a subgroup of Aut(G).

Proposition 5.6: Aut(Z/nZ)≅(Z/nZ)×Aut(\mathbb Z/n \mathbb Z) \cong (\mathbb Z/n \mathbb Z)^{\times}Aut(Z/nZ)≅(Z/nZ)×

Classification of Finitely Generated Abelian Groups

First, we need to understand that mathematicians consider only the abstract structure of groups. So as long as two groups are isomorphic, we consider them as the “same”, no matter the actual elements or operations of the specific group. We’d like to classify groups into their “representatives” up to isomporphism. For example, groups of order 4 are either isomorphic to C4C_4C4​ or C2×C2C_2 \times C_2C2​×C2​ (called the Klein four-group).

Definition 5.7: Finitely Generated Groups

A group GGG is finitely generated if there exists g1,⋯ ,gn∈Gg_1, \cdots, g_n \in Gg1​,⋯,gn​∈G for some finite nnn such that G=⟨g1,⋯ ,gn⟩G = \langle g_1, \cdots, g_n \rangleG=⟨g1​,⋯,gn​⟩.

Theorem 5.8: Chinese Remainder If n1,n2,⋯ ,nrn_1, n_2, \cdots, n_rn1​,n2​,⋯,nr​ are relatively prime integers, Gn1×Gn2×⋯×Gnr≅Gn1×⋯×nrG_{n_1} \times G_{n_2} \times \cdots \times G_{n_r} \cong G_{n_1 \times \cdots \times n_r}Gn1​​×Gn2​​×⋯×Gnr​​≅Gn1​×⋯×nr​​.

Theorem 5.9: Fundamental Theorem of Abelian Groups

If GGG is a finitely generated abelian group, then we have G≅Z×⋯×Z×Z/n1×⋯Z/nkG \cong \mathbb Z \times \cdots \times \mathbb Z \times \mathbb Z/n_1 \times \cdots \mathbb Z/n_kG≅Z×⋯×Z×Z/n1​×⋯Z/nk​ such that n1,⋯ ,nk≥2n_1, \cdots, n_k \geq 2n1​,⋯,nk​≥2 and ni+1∣nin_i+1 \mid n_ini​+1∣ni​ for i∈[k−1]i \in [k-1]i∈[k−1]. This decomposition is unique.

Equivalently, put ∣G∣=p1a1p2a2⋯prar|G| = p_1^{a_1}p_2^{a_2}\cdots p_r^{a_r}∣G∣=p1a1​​p2a2​​⋯prar​​, then G≅A1×⋯×ArG \cong A_1 \times \cdots \times A_rG≅A1​×⋯×Ar​ where Ai=piaiA_i = p_i^{a_i}Ai​=piai​​. Moreover, for each AiA_iAi​, Ai≅Z/pb1×⋯×Z/pbmA_i \cong \mathbb Z/p^{b_1} \times \cdots \times \mathbb Z/p^{b_m}Ai​≅Z/pb1​×⋯×Z/pbm​ where b1≥⋯≥bmb_1 \geq \cdots \geq b_mb1​≥⋯≥bm​. This decomposition is unique.

Example 5.1: Fundamental Theorem of Abelian Groups

Let G=Z/8×Z/6×Z/15G = \mathbb Z/8 \times \mathbb Z/6 \times \mathbb Z/15G=Z/8×Z/6×Z/15, then G≅Z/120×Z/6≅Z/8×Z/2×Z/3×Z/3×Z/5G \cong \mathbb Z/120 \times \mathbb Z/6 \cong \mathbb Z/8 \times \mathbb Z/2 \times \mathbb Z/3 \times \mathbb Z/3 \times \mathbb Z/5G≅Z/120×Z/6≅Z/8×Z/2×Z/3×Z/3×Z/5.

Proof. The theorem can be proven by induction on the size of a group. We also need the technique of “taking a group to a power”. The full proof can be found here.

Semi-Direct Products

Definition/Theorem 5.10: Semi-Direct Products

Let HHH and KKK be groups and let ϕ\phiϕ be a homomorphism from KKK to Aut(H)Aut(H)Aut(H). Define the group G={(h,k)∣h∈H,k∈K}G = \{(h,k)|h\in H, k \in K\}G={(h,k)∣h∈H,k∈K}, with the binary operation (h1,k1)∘(h2,k2)=(h1ϕ(k1)(h2),k1k2)(h_1, k_1) \circ (h_2, k_2) = (h_1 \phi(k_1)(h_2), k_1k_2)(h1​,k1​)∘(h2​,k2​)=(h1​ϕ(k1​)(h2​),k1​k2​). GGG is the semi-direct product of HHH and KKK, denoted as G=H⋊KG = H \rtimes KG=H⋊K. We have that

  1. GGG is a group, and ∣G∣=∣H∣∣K∣|G| = |H||K|∣G∣=∣H∣∣K∣.
  2. H≅{(h,eK)∈G:h∈H},K≅{(eH,k)∈G:k∈K}H \cong \{(h,e_K) \in G: h \in H\}, K \cong \{(e_H,k) \in G: k \in K\}H≅{(h,eK​)∈G:h∈H},K≅{(eH​,k)∈G:k∈K}.
  3. H⊴GH \trianglelefteq GH⊴G.
  4. H∩K=eH \cap K = eH∩K=e.
  5. khk−1=ϕ(k)(h)khk^{-1} = \phi(k)(h)khk−1=ϕ(k)(h) for all h∈H,k∈Kh \in H, k \in Kh∈H,k∈K.

Proof. The first claim can be shown by directly checking the associativity and inverse of the binary operation, using the definitions of homomorphisms. The second claim can be shown by defining isomorphisms. With the second claim, we can identify HHH with {(h,eK)∈G:h∈H}\{(h,e_K) \in G: h \in H\}{(h,eK​)∈G:h∈H} and KKK with {(eH,k)∈G:k∈K}\{(e_H,k) \in G: k \in K\}{(eH​,k)∈G:k∈K}, or h∈Hh \in Hh∈H with (h,e)(h, e)(h,e) and k∈Kk \in Kk∈K with (e,k)(e, k)(e,k). The following claims are thus straightforward to show.

Proposition 5.11: Recognition of Semi-Direct Products

If GGG is a group, and HHH is a normal subgroup and KKK is a subgroup such that HK=GHK = GHK=G and H∩K={e}H \cap K = \{e\}H∩K={e}, then G≅H⋊ϕKG \cong H \rtimes_\phi KG≅H⋊ϕ​K, where ϕ:K→Aut(H)\phi: K \to Aut(H)ϕ:K→Aut(H) such that ϕ(k)(h)=khk−1\phi(k)(h) = khk^{-1}ϕ(k)(h)=khk−1.

Examples of Group Classification

Example 5.2: Groups of Order pqpqpq, p,qp, qp,q Primes

Assume WLOG that p<qp < qp<q. Let P∈Sylp(G),Q∈Sylq(G)P \in Syl_p(G), Q \in Syl_q(G)P∈Sylp​(G),Q∈Sylq​(G) be two subgroups. By the Sylow’s theorems, nq≡1mod  qn_q \equiv 1 \mod qnq​≡1modq and nq∣pn_q \mid pnq​∣p, but we assume p<qp < qp<q, so nq=1n_q = 1nq​=1. We also have np≡1mod  pn_p \equiv 1 \mod pnp​≡1modp and np∣qn_p \mid qnp​∣q.

If p∤q−1p \nmid q-1p∤q−1, np=1n_p = 1np​=1 is the only possibility. Then G≅P×QG \cong P \times QG≅P×Q, a cyclic group.

Else if p∣q−1p \mid q-1p∣q−1, it is possible that np=qn_p = qnp​=q. Then G≅Q⋊ϕPG \cong Q \rtimes_\phi PG≅Q⋊ϕ​P, where ϕ:P→Aut(Q)≅Z/q−1\phi: P \to Aut(Q) \cong \mathbb Z/q-1ϕ:P→Aut(Q)≅Z/q−1. PPP is a cyclic group, say P=⟨y⟩P = \langle y \rangleP=⟨y⟩, and Aut(Q)Aut(Q)Aut(Q) is also cyclic and contains a unique subgroup of order ppp (by classification of finitely generated abelian groups), say <γ>∈Q<\gamma> \in Q<γ>∈Q. ϕi(y)=γi\phi_i(y) = \gamma^iϕi​(y)=γi for i=0,⋯ ,p−1i = 0, \cdots, p-1i=0,⋯,p−1. When i=0i=0i=0, the trivial homomorphism gives the direct product G≅P×QG \cong P \times QG≅P×Q. The other p−1p-1p−1 homomorphisms gives p−1p-1p−1 isomorphic non-abelian groups G≅Q⋊ϕiPG \cong Q \rtimes_{\phi_i} PG≅Q⋊ϕi​​P.

Example 5.3: Groups of Order 30

First, factor out 30=2×3×530 = 2 \times 3 \times 530=2×3×5. By the Sylow’s theorems, n3=1 or 10,n5=1 or 6n_3 = 1 \text{ or } 10, n_5 = 1 \text{ or } 6n3​=1 or 10,n5​=1 or 6. Either n3=1n_3 = 1n3​=1 or n5=1n_5 = 1n5​=1, otherwise the number of elements exceeds 30, which means one of them is normal in GGG, so the product of a 3-group and a 5-group is a group of order 15, and from Example 5.2, we have that it is isomorphic to Z/15\mathbb Z/15Z/15. Let the group be H≅Z/15H \cong \mathbb Z/15H≅Z/15. Note that HHH is normal in GGG since it has index of 2. Let KKK be a group of order 2. Since G=HK,H∩K=eG = HK, H \cap K = eG=HK,H∩K=e, we have G≅H⋊ϕKG \cong H \rtimes_\phi KG≅H⋊ϕ​K, hwere ϕ:K→Aut(H)≅(Z/15)×≅Z/4×Z/2\phi: K \to Aut(H) \cong (\mathbb Z/15)^\times \cong \mathbb Z/4 \times \mathbb Z/2ϕ:K→Aut(H)≅(Z/15)×≅Z/4×Z/2. Note that KKK contains only the identity and an element of order 2. Let H=⟨a⟩×⟨b⟩≅Z/5Z/3H = \langle a \rangle \times \langle b \rangle \cong \mathbb Z/5 \mathbb Z/3H=⟨a⟩×⟨b⟩≅Z/5Z/3. There are only three elements in Aut(H)Aut(H)Aut(H) of order 2:

  • ψ1∈Aut(H)\psi_1 \in Aut(H)ψ1​∈Aut(H), where ψ1(a)=a−1\psi_1(a) = a^{-1}ψ1​(a)=a−1, ψ1(b)=b\psi_1(b) = bψ1​(b)=b
  • ψ2∈Aut(H)\psi_2 \in Aut(H)ψ2​∈Aut(H), where ψ2(a)=a,ψ2(b)=b−1\psi_2(a) = a, \psi_2(b) = b^{-1}ψ2​(a)=a,ψ2​(b)=b−1
  • ψ3∈Aut(H)\psi_3 \in Aut(H)ψ3​∈Aut(H), where ψ3(a)=a−1,ψ2(b)=b−1\psi_3(a) = a^{-1}, \psi_2(b) = b^{-1}ψ3​(a)=a−1,ψ2​(b)=b−1

Corresponding to these three elements are three homomorphisms:

  • G≅Q⋊ϕ1P≅Z/5×D6G \cong Q \rtimes_{\phi_1} P \cong \mathbb Z/5 \times D_6G≅Q⋊ϕ1​​P≅Z/5×D6​
  • G≅Q⋊ϕ2P≅Z/3×D10G \cong Q \rtimes_{\phi_2} P \cong \mathbb Z/3 \times D_{10}G≅Q⋊ϕ2​​P≅Z/3×D10​
  • G≅Q⋊ϕ3P≅D30G \cong Q \rtimes_{\phi_3} P \cong D_{30}G≅Q⋊ϕ3​​P≅D30​

References

[1] Siegel, Kyler. MATH GU4041 Introduction to Modern Algebra I. Department of Mathematics, Columbia University. 2019.

[2] Dummit, David and Foote, Richard. Abstract Algebra. Third Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 2004.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 05 - Direct and Semi-Direct Products, and Group Classification
frontmatter.description: This is the fifth post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series, and the last post about group theory. In this post, we will finalize our tool box by introducing automorphisms, direct products, and semi-direct products. Finally, we can start to harvest our efforts with group classification.
